title: Simplify logger
body:
This PR adds a simplified logging system, with two primary methods:
- `Logger#log(String) :: void` (for normal logging)
- `Logger#debug(String) :: void` (for debug logging)

This helps dramatically simplify logging infrastructure, as well as enabling simpler toggling of log modes.

The configuration values for the Logger have also been updated:
- `logger :: Function` - function to log output to (both normal + debug)
- `silent :: Boolean` - whether to log default normal messages or not (`--silent` flag)
- `debug  :: Boolean` - whether or not to log debug output (`--debug` flag)

Additionally, the following CLI flags are supported re: logging:
- `--silent` disables normal logging (will override all other settings)
- `--debug` enables debug logging

Deprecation notices have been added for old log methods, with first-run messages to this effect.

This change should have negligible impact on end-users, with minor inconvenience for library developers, as they need to switch their logging function calls over.

Logging configuration is still possible via both `Cylon.Config.update(Object)`, and directly calling `Cylon.Logger.setup(Object)`.

title: Support asynchronous robot commands
body:
Robot interactions with the real world sometimes require asynchronous calls to subsystems.  The existing command system, however, expects results to be returned immediately upon return from the command.

Instead of supporting an alternate command/callback syntax, I propose with pull request #247 a mechanism of returning [promises](https://www.google.com/search?q=javascript+promises) for asynchronous commands.  Adding this support turned out to be a fairly simple change in the API comand processor.

title: Support asynchronous robot commands
body:
This pull request adds support for robot commands that aren't able to produce results synchronously.

If a command cannot produce immediate results, it returns a [promise](https://www.google.com/search?q=javascript+promises) instead of the results.

Clients of the command can use the promise directly if it knows the command is asynchronous  - usually from the documentation. If the client doesn't know if a command is asynchronous, it can inspect the result to see if it's `then`able.  This was the change made to the API in this pull request.

This resolved an issue in my device where the results couldn't be returned immediately upon command invocation. The alternatives were awkward - either require the client to wait a bit and call a different command for the results, or wait on a custom event designated for the results of the command. Neither option was appropriate because the results may have come from a different caller.

title: Remove Connection and Device classes
body:
This PR removes the Connection and Device classes.

Instead, they are now replaced with Connection and Device functions, that return a specific Adaptor/Driver respectively.

This eliminates the 'buffer' issues resulting from having an intermediate class between the Robot and the hardware it's communicating with.

I've tested this setup with modified versions of `cylon-leapmotion` and `cylon-firmata`, and all seems to work in use.

The module refactors for this changeset is a bit more involved, but there are some simple rules to describe the changes:
- in Adaptor subclasses, where you would refer to `this.connection`, now refer to `this`.
- in Driver subclasses, where you would refer to `this.connection`, now refer to `this.adaptor`.
- in Driver subclasses, where you would refer to `this.device`, now refer to `this`.

The utility functions on Basestar (proxying methods) have been updated for these changes, as have the appropriate API methods.

The Device and Connection functions currently share enough common code that they can possibly be merged at some point.

Since Drivers should be directly communicating with Adaptors, this facilitates that, rather than roundtripping through the Connection where something else can go wrong. This also allows direct event listening on Adaptors, rather than hoping the correct events were propagated to the Connection.

title: Remove node-namespace and class cruft
body:
This PR removes `node-namespace` from Cylon, and dramatically reduces class cruft introduced in the transition from CoffeeScript to plain JavaScript.

Additionally, this PR significantly overhauls the core of the Cylon module, replacing the `Cylon.Master` singleton with a simple JS object that will never be duplicated, due to Node's caching of required modules.

This PR also requries changes in _all_ Cylon adaptors before it can be released. Whereas previously child modules could rely on `Cylon.Adaptor` or `Cylon.Driver` being present in the global namespace, now they'll have to manually require Cylon to access it.

e.g.

``` javascript
var Cylon = require('cylon');

var SpheroAdaptor = function SpheroAdaptor();

subclass(SpheroAdaptor, Cylon.Adaptor);
```

This also gives us an excuse to clean up the similar class cruft in all of those modules. When all this is done, a new release of Cylon + adaptor modules can be cut.

I've left the Logger and Utils in global namespace for now, Utils because it makes sense for the utility function and Logger because I'm not sure what the best thing to do with it is yet.

I'm comfortable with this PR sitting around for a while for discussion, so please nitpick.

body:
This PR is meant to be a preview of some changes I'd like to see made to Cylon:
- removal of leftover CoffeeScript class cruft
- removal of `node-namespace`

I'm unsure if we actually want to fully remove `node-namespace` at this point, as the layout it gives is at the heart of our current code organization system (at least in cylon-core).

Ultimately, `node-namespace` isn't really doing that much that we can't replicate manually; and adds another dependency that we don't need. I think it's more of a training wheel for Ruby developers who miss the modules/class nesting that's so easy/common in that language.

In modules, I think it's easier to consider dropping `node-namespace`, as they have a single point of entry and Cylon doesn't really care where the actual classes live.

title: Replace Express.IO/Socket.IO with Express/SSEs
body:
This PR replaces Express-IO and the included Socket.IO event listening implementation with plain ExpressJS and a simple Server-Sent-Events implementation.

I believe Server-Sent-Events are a better fit for this use case, as there is no two-way communication involved, the setup is much simpler than for WebSockets, and there is a lot less happening on the client and server to go wrong.

Additionally, since Server-Sent-Events are simply long-held HTTP connections, it should be trivial to add support in environments that would otherwise not support SSEs or WebSockets.
